summary: three main subtypes of swine influenza virus (H1N1, H3N2, and H1N2) have circulated in pigs worldwide. in march 2009, a new swine-origin H1N1 virus became a pandemic. pig infections with the new H1N1 virus have then been observed in multiple countries. co-infections of swine influenza virus and S. suis in pigs contribute to severe pneumonia. fewer studies have examined swine influenza and S. suis co-infection in pigs. pathogenesis is not yet fully elucidated. an SS2 strain, 05ZY, was isolated from the brain of a diseased piglet in Sichuan Province, china in 2005. the pigs were randomly divided into four groups with three pigs per group. each group was housed in an isolated room. the SS2 and SS2 groups were inoculated intranasally with 2 mL of 107.0 EID50/mL of the H1N1 swine influenza virus. the other pigs were inoculated with PBS containing 106.0 CFU/mL SS2 strain ZY05. all pigs were humanely euthanized by intravenous injection of sodium pentobarbital. bacterial and bacterial isolation At specified time points, the collected nasal swabs were inserted into vials containing 1.5 mL of sterile PBS supplemented with 100 U/mL penicillin and streptomycin. to prevent cross-contamination, separate sterile instruments were used to collect the lungs of pigs from each group. genes with significant similarities (greater than 70%) to transcripts in the nr database were then examined using hierarchical cluster (Ver. 3.0) and treeView (Ver. 1.1.1) analyses. all DE genes were identified by setting a fold change (FC) > 1.5 and p 0.05 as the criteria. RNA was reversely transcribed in a 20l reaction mixture. a value of P 0.05 was considered statistically significant. the study was approved by the Biological Studies Animal Care and Use Committee in Hubei Province, china. the two experiments were performed at the same time and under same conditions. each group was inoculated intranasally with 2 mL of 107.0 EID50/mL of the H1N1 swine influenza virus. the other pigs were inoculated with PBS. at least 6 sections per lung from each group were examined microscopically for tissue damage, necrosis, apoptosis, and inflammatory cellular infiltration. dal lobes were embedded in formalin and embedded in paraffin, sectioned at 5m, and stained with hematoxylin and eosin. the hybridization data were normalized using Agilent Feature Extraction software. all differentially expressed (DE) genes were then examined using hierarchical cluster (Ver. 3.0) and treeView (Ver. 1.1.1) analyses. the raw and processed data in this study have been deposited in NCBI’s Gene expression omnibus. t-tests were used to compare virus titers, gene expressions, lung pathological damage score, and the apoptosis rate among infection groups. ized on day 6 and the macroscopic lesions of lungs tissues were estimated visually. more serious lung pathological damage was caused by co-infection, including hyperemia, necrosis, bleeding, and consolidation, compared with separate infections. pigs were PBS-control infected with H1N1, SS2 and H1N1-SS2. on day 6 of the experiment, lungs were removed and underwent Hematoxylin and eosin stain. the microscopic lesions of lung tissues from each group showed different extent of acute pneumonia. swabs were collected from the right nostrils of pigs every other day. supernatants were collected and viruses were qualified as LgEID50. at the day 6 of the experiment, all pigs were humanely euthanized. inflammatory response and apoptosis were more intensely activated in the H1N1-SS2 group compared with the H1N1 and SS2 groups. more DE genes were clustered in the immune and inflammation response (cytokine–cytokine receptor interaction, MAPK signaling, Toll-like receptor (TLR) signaling, JAK-STAT signaling pathway, antigen processing and presentation) -infection significantly regulated the mRNA expression of several chemokine and chemokine receptor genes, including CCL3 (1.62-fold), CX3CL1 (1.7-fold), CXCL16 (0.56-fold), CCR1 (2.23-fold), and CXCR4 (1.55-fold) the pro-inflammatory cytokine TNF- was not significantly regulated, but five tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily genes were significantly regulated. skeletal muscle GEM 404772 -1.63 CD4 molecule CD4 404704 1.58 toll-like receptor 6 TLR6 396621 1.58 Inflammatory response sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor 3 S1PR3 expression pattern indicated the reliability of the microarray analysis. the coincident expression pattern indicated the reliability of the analysis. clinical signs were observed daily starting from 1 d before challenge (day 0) the H1N1 and H1N1-SS2 groups experienced fever, which started on day 1, reaching to 40.8°C and 40.9°C, respectively, on day 3. pigs also exhibited high fever (41.5°C, 41.8°C, and 41.5°C) all groups except the control exhibited different degrees of pathological damage. extensive lung damages were observed in H1N1-SS2 group. however, H1N1 and SS2 groups showed lesser lung damages. the microscopic lesions of lung tissues from each group showed different extent of acute pneumonia with pathological changes. alveolar wall thickening, bleeding (red arrow), debris in the lumen (green arrow), erythrocyte effusion (blue arrow) and accumulation of inflammatory cells. swabs were collected from all pigs every 2 d after inoculation. all pigs were humanely euthanized and lungs were collected and homogenized in sterile PBS. p-value less than 0.01 was noted with a single-asterisk. gene expression profiles of porcine lungs were compared with that in the control group. pathway analysis was performed on the DE genes. more genes were clustered in the immune and inflammation response. apoptosis in the H1N1-SS2 group. cytokine TNF- was not significantly regulated, five tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily genes were significantly regulated in the co-infection group. IL-8, CCL2 and IL-6 were also significantly increased in the co-infection group. interleukin 17D IL17D 100738902 2.16 chemokine (C-C motif) ligand 2 CCL2 397422 -1.99 interferon (alpha, beta and omega) receptor 1 IFNAR1 396658 1.89 vascular endothelial growth factor C VEGFC 100127470 -1.87 CD163 molecule CD163 397031 -1.84 interleukin 2 IL2 396868 1.71 toll-like EC5A 397050 -2.21 chitinase, acidic CHIA 100156433 1.99 Fc fragment of IgA FCAR 100144539 1.99 cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-associated protein 4 CTLA4 397286 1.80 dipeptzzidyl-peptidase 8 DPP8 100155833 -1.53 interleukin 1 receptor, type II IL1R2 100628112 14.28 CD14 molecule CD the DE genes associated with immune and inflammatory responses were assigned based on GO term and manual annotation. manual annotations were listed in italics. IL-1 receptor 2-Bos taurus Bovine, partial 98% IL1R2 100628112 4.56 neutrophil cytosolic factor 4, 40kDa NCF4 100152055 3.34 myeloid differentiation primary response gene (88) MYD88 396646 2.32 oncostatin M receptor OSMR 100519398 2.31 toll-like receptor 9 TLR9 397007 2.27 chemokine (C-C motif) receptor 1 CCR1 414374 XCL16 396735 -1.78 SMAD family member 1 SMAD1 397016 1.75 interferon (alpha, beta and omega) receptor 1 IFNAR1 396658 1.74 nuclear factor of kappa light polypeptide gene enhancer in B-cells inhibitor, alpha NFKBIA 406188 1.74 interferon gamma receptor 1 IFNGR1 100152238 1.73 bone morphogenetic protein receptor, type IB BM manual annotations were listed in italics. many genes with multiple functions were only listed in one category. expression of genes related to inflammation and apoptosis by qRT-PCR. the H1N1 and SS2 infections caused significant apoptosis compared with the control. however, H1N1-SS2 co-infection notably triggered the significantly more cell apoptosis rate compared with the control. this result was consistent with the modification of the significantly regulated genes involved in apoptosis by each infection group. PDCD4 100157112 -1.76 tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily, member 1B TNFRSF1B 100037306 1.64 H1N1-SS2 caspase 10, apoptosis-related cysteine peptidase CASP10 100154896 1.55 granzyme B (granzyme 2, cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-associated serine esterase 1) GZMB 100233184 4.29 Fas ligand (TNF the de genes associated with apoptosis were based on GO term and manual annotation. many genes with multiple functions were only listed in one category. genes H1N1 group SS2 group H1N1-SS2 group Microarray fold change qRT-PCR fold change qRT-PCR fold change qRT-PCR p-value NCF4 NS -0.21 0.0010 1.64 6.73 0.0010 3.34 17.56 0.0010 CD14 NS 2.70 0.0010 5.23 13.65 0.0010 4.96 6.37 0.0010 IL17D NS 2.21 0.0010 2.07 4.54 0.0 the augmented host response is considered a critical factor for the severe pathogenicity of influenza virus infection in humans. a genome expression analysis was performed to obtain comprehensive information on the host responses in the lungs of infected pigs through H1N1, SS2 and H1N1-SS2 infections. the increased virulence of co-infection might be attributed to the enhanced viral replication or SS2 growth. several genes in the TLR signaling were significantly but differently regulated in each infection group. for example, CD14 has been identified as an LPS receptor [21], which can bind to the LPS-binding protein (LBP) [22]. LBP catalyzes the transfer of LPS to CD14, which then mediates the transfer of LPS to the membrane, where LPS binds with the TLR4-MD-2 complex. the role of TLR4 and its downstream signaling in co-infection are worthy of further investigations. cytokine is an important part of the host defensive system that helps eliminate pathogens by recruiting inflammatory cells. however, overabundant cytokine production could cause pathology. signaling pathway has been found to be greatly induced. it may suggest that the significant activation of the MAPK pathway plays some important roles in the pro-inflammatory responses caused by co-infection. CD163 was significantly upregulated in the SS2 and H1N1-SS2 infection groups. the PPAR pathway has an important role in anti-inflammatory response. it can reduce several pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines. this result indicated that the host tried to terminate over-induced inflammatory responses. in the present study, several genes, as immune cell markers, were moderately upregulated, which contained CD14, CD1D, and CD163 in the SS2 and H1N1-SS2 groups. however, CD163 and CD1D were both downregulated, and CD14 was not significantly changed in H1N1 group. more genes related to complement system were upregulated, including C1R, C1S, C5AR1, C6 and KNG1. apoptosis was observed in the lungs from all infection groups. increased robust apoptosis was induced by the H1N1-SS2 co-infection. co-infection led to much higher apoptosis rate compared with separate infections. co-infection by H1N1 and SS2 could potentiate virulence by causing severe apoptosis. co-infections of influenza virus and SS2 are highly complex, which makes the mechanism of the increased virulence much complex. factors contributing to the complex may include infection doses of pathogens, the secondary infection time, different pathogens with various virulence, and even environment factors. the results showed that MYD88 was significantly upregulated in the H1N1-SS2 group at 2.32-fold compared with that in the other two infection groups. however, the role of TLR4 and its downstream signaling in co-infection are worthy of further investigations. MYD88, NFKB1, TIRAP, TLR4 and TLR9 were upregulated from 1.63- to 2.32-fold in this group. these genes are all involved in the TLR signaling pathway. MAPK, a key pathway that regulates the synthesis of numerous cytokines, chemokines, and other inflammatory mediators, was also significantly regulated. CYBB is related to lung inflammation caused by influenza virus. the increased NADPH oxidase expression implied more ROS production and would lead to oxidative stress, which caused more severe inflammatory damage in H1N1-SS2 group. NK cells, CD4+ and CD8+ T cells, and neutrophils increased upon influenza virus infection. the increase of the immune cells is not only beneficial for clearing the virus, but may also contribute to pulmonary inflammation. LGMN, a cysteine protease, was reported to be implicated in human regulatory T cell function [52] NK cells play an important role in the immune response to viral infections, which can activate dendritic cells and also secret T helper type 1 (Th1) cytokines to augment cytotoxic T cell responses. apoptosis was observed in the lungs from all infection groups. increased robust apoptosis was induced by the H1N1-SS2 co-infection. the microarray analysis results also indicated that more genes involved in apoptosis pathway were regulated. the H1N1 infection with 107.0 EID50/mL could cause flu symptoms within 3 days. SS2 challenge with 106.0 CFU/mL could lead to severe typical symptoms within 24 hours. many genes reported to play important roles in inflammatory response were not fund to be significantly changed. Lungs were removed on day 6 and were fixed in formalin and embedded in paraffin, sectioned at 5m, and stained with hematoxylin and eosin for further histopathologic evaluation. (1.1MB, tif) S5 Data. Microscopic lung lesions in pigs from SS2 group. many genes with multiple functions were only listed in one category. manual annotations were listed in italics.
